respStmt.name: Former Owner - Author of Handwritten Annotations

publicationStmt.p: Published by the Open Publishing Unit of The Pennsylvania State University Libraries.

monogr.author: Francis Beaumont
John Fletcher
monogr.title: Comedies and Tragedies Written by Francis Beavmont and Iohn Fletcher, Gentlemen. Never printed before, And now published by the Authours Originall Copies.

imprint.pubPlace: The Princes Armes in St. Pauls Church-yard

encodingDesc.p: This document is a simplified "true-to-text" XML version of The Sea Voyage based on Pennsylvania State University's annotated copy of the 1647 Beaumont & Fletcher first folio. Major textual elements and attributes have been captured based on how they appear in the folio. Whenever possible, editorial interventions have been minimalized or avoided entirely. This document is meant to serve as a pedagogical tool by which students of Early Modern literature can learn to construct edited XML versions of the play.

castList.head: The Perſons repreſented in the Play.

castItem.roleDesc: a French Pirat, in love with Aminta.
a merry Gentleman, friend to Albert.
a noble Gentleman of Portugal, Husband to Roſellia.

castList.castItem: Nicuſa Nephew to Sebaſtian, both caſt upon a deſart Iſland.

castItem.roleDesc: Miſtriſs to Albert, a noble French Virgin.
Daughter to Roſellia, in love with Albert.

castGroup.head: Three Ladies, Members of the Female Common-wealth.

lg.l: LAy her aloofe, the Sea grows dangerous,

How it ſpits againſt the clouds, how it
capers,
And how the fiery Element frights it back!
There be devils dancing in the aire, I think
I ſaw a Dolphin hang ith hornes of the moone
Shot from a wave: hey day, hey day,
How ſhe kicks and yerks?
Down with 'e main Maſt, lay her at huIl,
Farle up all her Linnens, and let her ride it out.
Sheele never brook it Maſter.
Shees ſo deep laden, that ſheele buldge;
Hang her.
Can ſhe not buffet with a ſtorm a little?
How it toſſes her! ſhe reeles like a Drunkard.
We have diſcovered the Land Sir,
Pray lets make in, ſhee's ſo drunke; elſe,
She may chance to caſt up all her Lading.

Sland in, ſland in, we are all loſt els, loſt and
periſht.
Steer her a Star-boord there.
Beare in with all the Sayle we can, ſee Maſter
See, What a clap of Thunder there is,
What a face of heaven, how dredfully it looks?
Thou raſcall, thou fearfuIl rogue, thou haſt bin
I ſeet in thy face, thou haſt been mumbling,
When we are ſplit you ſlave; is this a time,
To diſcourage our friends with your cold orrizons?
Call up the Boatſwaine; how it ſtorms; holla.
What ſhall we doe Maſter?
Caſt over all her lading? ſhe will not ſwimme

An houre elſe; Enter Albert
Franvile
La-mure
Tibalt de pont.
Morillat.
The ſtorm is lowd,
We cannot heare one another,
What's the coaſt?
We know not yet; ſhall we make in?
What comfort Saylers?
I never ſaw, ſince I have known the Sea,
(Which has been this twenty yeers) ſo rude a tempeſt.
In what State are we?
Dangerous enough Captain,
We have ſprung five leakes, and no little ones;
Still rage; beſides her ribs are open;
Her rudder almoſt ſpent; prepare your ſelves;
And have good courages, death comes but once,
And let him come in all his frights.
Is't not poſſible,
To make in toth' Land? 'tis here before us.
Here hard by Sir.
Death is neerer Gentlemen.
Yet doe not cry, lets dye like men.
Shal's hoyſe the Boat out, Enter Amint.
And goe all at one caſt? the more the merrier.
You are too haſty Mounſieur,
Do ye long to be ith Fiſh-market before your time?
Hold her up there.
O miſerable Fortune,
Nothing but horrour ſounding in mine eares,
No minute to promiſe to my frighted ſoule.
Peace woman,
We ha ſtorms enough already; no more howling.
Gentle Maſter.
Clap this woman under hatches.
Prethee ſpeake mildly to her.
Can no help?
None that I know.
No promiſe from your goodneſſe?

Am I a God? for heavens ſake ſtoaw this
woman.
Goe: take your gilt Prayer Booke;
And to your buſineſſe; winck and die,
There an old Haddock ſtayes for ye.
Muſt I dye here in all the frights, the terrors,
The thouſand ſeverall ſhapes, death triumphes in?
No friend to councell me?
Have Peace ſweet Miſtreſſe.
No kindreds teares upon me? Oh! my country!
No gentle hand to cloſe mine eyes?
Be comforted, heaven has the ſame
Power ſtill, and the ſame mercy.
Oh! that wave will devour me!
Carry her down Captaine;
Or by theſe hands, I'le give no more direction,
Let the Ship ſinck or ſwimme; we ha nere better luck,
When we ha ſuch ſtoage as theſe trinkets with us,
Theſe ſweet ſin-breeders; how can heaven ſmile on us,
When ſuch a burthen of iniquity
Lies tumbling like a potion in our Ships belly? Exit.
A way with her, and if ſhe have a Prayer,
That's fit for ſuch an houre, let her ſay't quickly,
And ſeriouſly. Exit.
Come, I ſee it cleer Lady, come in,
And take ſome comfort. I'le ſtay with ye.

Where ſhould I ſtay? to what end ſhould I
hope,
Am I not circled round with miſery?
Confuſions in their full heights dwell about me:
O Mounſier Albert, How am I bound to curſe ye,
If curſes could redeeme me? how to hate ye?
You forc't me from my quiet, from my friends;
Even from their Armes, that were as deere to me,
As day light is, or comfort to the wretched;
You forc't my friends from their peacefull reſt,
Some your relentles ſword gave their laſt groanes;
Would I had there been numbred;
And to fortunes never ſatisfied afflictions,
Ye turn'd my Brother; and thoſe few friends I'd left
Like deſperate creatures, to their own feares
And the worlds ſtubborn pitties: Oh merciles.
Sweet Miſtreſſe.
And whether they are wandred to avoyd ye,
Or whether dead and no kind earth to cover 'em;
Was this a lovers part? but heaven has found ye,
And in his lowd voyce, his voyce of thunder,
And in the mutiny of his deep wonders,
He tels ye now, ye weepe too late:
Let theſe tears tell how I honour ye;
Ye know deer Lady, ſince ye were mine,
How truly I have lov'd ye, how ſanctimoniouſly
Obſerv'd your honour; not one laſcivious word,

Not one touch Lady; no, not a hope that might not
render me
The unpolluted ſervant of your Chaſtity;
For you I put to Sea, to ſeek your Brother;
Your Captain, yet your ſlave, that his redemption,
If he be living, where the Sunne has circuit,
May expiate your rigor, and my raſhneſſe.
The Storm grows greater; what ſhall we do?
Let's in;
And aske heavens mercy; my ſtrong mind yet preſages,
Through aIl theſe dangers, we ſhall ſee a day yet

Shall Crown your pious hopes, and my faire wiſhes.
Exit.

div.stage:
Enter Maſter, Saylors, Gentlemen,
Boatſwayne and Surgeon.

lg.l: It muſt all over boord.
lt cleers to Sea-ward maſt.
Fling o're the lading there, and let's lighten her;
All the meat, and the Cakes, we are all gone elſe;
That we may finde her Leakes, and hold her up;
Yet ſave ſome little Bisket for the Lady,
Til we come to the Land.
Muſt my goods over too?
Why honeſt Maſter? here lies all my money;
The money I ha wrackt by uſurie,
To buy new Lands and Lordſhips in new Countryes,
'Cauſe I was baniſht from mine own
I ha been this tweenty yeers a raiſing it.
Out with it:

The devils are got together by the eares, who ſhall
have it;
And here they quarrell in the cIouds.
I am undone Sir:

And be undone, 'tis better then we
periſh.
O ſave one Cheſt of Plate.
A way with it, luſtily Saylors;
It was ſome pawne, that he has got unjuſtly;
Down with it low enough, and let Crabs breed in't;

Over with the Truncks too. Enter
Albert.
Take mine and ſpare not;
We muſt over with all.
Will ye throw away my Lordſhip
That I ſold, put it into clothes and neceſſaries,
To goe to Sea with?
Over with it; I love to ſee a Lordſhip ſincke;
Sir you left no Wood upon't to bovy it up;
You might ha ſav'd it elſe.
I am undone for ever;

Why we are all undone; would you be only
happy?
Sir you may looſe too.
Thou lieſt; I ha nothing but my skinne,
And my Clothes; my ſword here, and my ſelf;
Two Crowns in my Pocket; two paire of Cards;
And three falſe Dice: I can ſwime like a Fiſh;
Raſcall, nothing to hinder me.
In with her of all hands.

Come gentlemen, come Captain, ye muſt helpe
all;
My life now for the Land,
'Tis high, and rocky, and full of perils;
How ever let's attempt it.
Then cheer luſtily my hearts. Exit.
Yes 'tis a Ship, I ſee it now, a tal Ship;
She has wrought luſtily for her deliverance;
Heavens mercy, what a wretched day has here been?
To ſtill and quiet minds, that knew no miſery,
It may ſeeme wretched, but with us 'tis ordinary;
Heaven has no Storm in ſtore, nor earth no terror,
That can ſeeme new to us.
'Tis true Nicuſa; if fortune were determin'd
To be wanton, and would wipe out the ſtories
Of mens miſeries: yet we two living,
We could croſſe her purpoſe; for 'tis impoſſible
She ſhould cure us, we are ſo excellent in our afflictions;
It would be more then glory to her blindnes,
And ſtile her power beyond her pride, to quit us.
Doe they live ſtill?
Yes, and make to harbour:
Moſt miſerable men; I greive their Fortunes.

How happy had they been, had the Sea cover'd
'em?
They leap from one calamity to another;

Had they been drown'd, they had ended all their
ſorrows.
What ſhowts of joy they make?
Alas poor wretches, had they but once experience
Of this Iſland, they'd turn their tunes to waylings;
Nay, to curſes.
That ever they ſet foot on ſuch calamities;
Here's nothing but rocks and barrennes,
Hunger, and cold to eat; here's no Vineyards
To cheere the heart of man, no Chriſtall Rivers
After his labour to refreſh his body,
If he be feeble; nothing to reſtore him,
But heavenly hopes; nature that made thoſe remedies,
Dares not come here, nor looke on our diſtreſſes,
For fear ſhe turn wilde like the place and barren.
O Uncle, yet a little memory of what we were,
'Twill be a little comfort in our calamities;
When we were ſeated in our bleſſed homes,
How happy in our kindreds, in our families,
In all our Fortunes?

Curſe on thoſe French Pirates, that diſplanted
us;
That flung us from that happineſſe we found there;

Conſtrain'd us to Sea, to ſave our lives, honours and our
riches,
With all we had, our kinſmen and our jewels,
In hope to finde ſome place free from ſuch robbers,
Where a mighty ſtorme ſeverd our Barkes,
That, where my wife, my daughter
And my noble Ladyes that went with her,
Virgins and loving ſoules, to ſcape thoſe Pirates.

They are living yet; ſuch goodneſſe cannot
periſh.
But never to me Cozen;
Never to me againe; what beares their Flag-ſtaves?
The Armes of France ſure;
Nay, doe not ſtart, we cannot be more miſerable;
Death is a cordial, now, come when it will.
They get to ſhore a pace, they'le flye as faſt

When once they find the place; what's that which ſwims
there?
A ſtrong young man Sir, with a handſome woman.
Hanging about his Neck.
That ſhewes ſome honour;
May thy brave charity what ere thou art,
Be ſpoken in a place, that may renown thee,
And not dye here.
The Boat it ſeemes turn'd over,
So forced to their ſhifts, yet all are landed,
They're Pirats on my life.
They will not rob us;
For none will take our miſery for riches:
Come Cozen, let's deſcend and try their pitties;
If we get off, a little hope walkes with us;
If not, we ſhall but load this wretched Iſland
With the ſame ſhadows ſtill that muſt grow ſhorter. Ex.

div.stage:
Enter Albert, Aminta, Tibalt, Morillat La-mure,
Maſter, Franvile, Surgeon, Saylors.

lg.l:
Wet come a ſhore my mates, we are ſafe arrived
yet.
Thanks to heavens goodneſſe, no man loſt;
The Ship rides faire to, and her leakes in good plight.
The weathers turn'd more courteous;
How does my deere?
Alas, how weake ſhe is and wet?
I am glad yet, I ſcapt with life;

Which certain Noble Captain, next to heavens
goodneſſe,
I muſt thanke you for, and which is more,
Acknowledge your deer tenderneſſe, your firme love
To your unworthy Miſtreſſe, and recant to
(Indeed I muſt) thoſe harſh opinions,
Thoſe cruell unkind thoughts, I heapt upon ye;
Farther then that, I muſt forget your Injuries.
So farre I am tyde, and fetred to your ſervice,
BeIeeve me I will learne to love.
I thank ye Madam,
And it ſhall be my practiſe to ſerve.
What cheere companions?
No great cheere Sir, a peece of ſouced Bisket
And halfe a hard egge; for the Sea has taken order;
Being young and ſtrong, we ſhall not ſurfet Captaine.
For mine own part, Ile Dance till I'm dry;
Come Surgeon, out with your Gliſter-pipe,
And ſtricke a Galliard.
What a brave day again;
And what faire weather, after ſo fowle a ſtorme?
I ant pleas'ed the Maſter, he might ha ſeen
This weather, and ha ſav'd our goods.

Never think on em, we have our lives and
healths.
I muſt think on em, and think
'Twas moſt maliciouſly done to undoe me.
And me to, I loſt all;
I hant another ſhirt to put upon me, nor Clothes
But theſe poor raggs; I had fifteen faire ſutes,
The worſt was cut upon Taffaty.
I am glad you ha loſt, give me thy hand,
Is thy skin whole? art thou not purl'd with ſcabbs?
No Ancient monuments of madam Venus?
Thou haſt a ſuit then will poſe the cunningſt Taylor,
That will never turn faſhion, nor forſake thee,
Till thy executors the wormes uncaſe thee,
They take off glorious ſutes Franvile: thou art happy,
Thou art delivered of em; here are no Brokers;
No Alchymiſts to turn 'em into Mettle;
Nor Leather'd Captaine's with Ladies to adore 'em;
Wilt thou ſee a dogfiſh riſe in one of thy brave doublets,
And tumble like a Tub to make thee merry,
Or an old Haddock riſe with thy hatcht ſword
Thou payd'ſt a hundred Crowns for?
A Mermayd in a mantle of your worſhips,
Or a Dolphin in your double ruffe?
Ye are merry, but if I take it thus,
If I be foyſted and jeer'd out of my goods.
Nor I, I vow thee.
Nor Maſter nor mate, I ſee your cunning,
O be not angry Gentlemen.
Yes Sir we have reaſon.
And ſome friends I can make.

What I did Gentlemen, was for the generall
ſafety.
If ye ayme at me, I am not ſo tame.
Pray take my councell Gallants.
Fight not till the Surgeon be well,
Hee's damnable Sea-ſick, and may ſpoyle all;
Beſides he has loſt his Fidleſtick, and the beſt
Box of Bores greaſe; why doe you make ſuch faces,
And hand your ſwords?
Who would ye fight with? Gentlemen?
Who has done ye wrong? for ſhame be better temper'd.
No ſooner come to give thankes for our ſafeties,
But we muſt raiſe new civill Broyles amongſt us

Inflame thoſe angry powers, to ſhower new vengeance
on us?
What can we expect for theſe unmanly murmers,
Theſe ſtrong temptations of their holy pitties,
But plagues in another kind, a fuller, ſo dreadfull,
That the ſinging ſtormes are ſlumbers to it?
Be men and rule your minds;
If you will needs fight Gentlemen,
And thinke to raiſe new riches by your valours,
Have at ye, I have little elſe to doe now
I have ſaid my Prayers; you ſay you have loſt,
And make your loſſe your quarrell,
And grumble at my Captaine here, and the Maſter,

Two worthy perſons; indeed too worthy for ſuch raſ-
cals,
Thou Galloone gallant, and Mamon you
That build on golden mountaines, thou money Maggot;
Come all draw your ſwords, ye ſay ye are miſerable.
Nay, hold good Tibalt.
Captaine, let me correct em;
I'le make ye ten times worſe, I will not leave em;
For look ye, fighting is as nouriſhing to me as eating,
I was born quarrelling.
Pray Sir.
I will not leave em skins to cover em;
Doe ye grumble, when ye are well ye rogues?
Noble Du-pont.
Ye have Clothes now: and ye prate.
Pray Gentlemen, for my ſake be at peace.
Let it become me to make all friends.
You have ſtopt our angers Lady.
This ſhewes noble.
'Tis well: 'tis very well: there's halfe a Bisket,
Break't amongſt ye all, and thank my bounty,
This is clothes & Plate too; come no more quarrelling.

But ha! what things are theſe, Enter
Sebaſtian
and Nicuſa.
Are they humane creatures?
I have heard of Sea-Calves.

They are no ſhaddows ſure, they have Leggs and
Armes.
They hang but lightly on though.
How they looke, are they mens faces?
They have Horſe-Tayles growing to em,
Goodly long maines.
Alas what ſunk eyes they have!
How they are crept in, as if they had been frighted!
Sure they are wretched men.
Where are their Wardrobs?
Looke ye Franvile, here are a cople of Courtiers.
They kneele, alas poore ſouIes.
What are ye? ſpeake; are ye alive,
Or wandring ſhaddows, that finde no peace on earth,
Till ye reveale ſome hidden ſecret?
We are men as you are;
Onely our miſeries make us ſeem Monſters.
If ever pitty dwelt in noble hearts;

We underſtand 'em too: pray marke em Gentle-
men;
Or that heaven is plea'sd with human charity;
If ever ye have heard the name of friendſhip?
Or ſuffered in your ſelves, the leaſt afflictions,
Have gentle Fathers that have bred ye tenderly,
And Mothers that have wept for your misfortunes,
Have mercy on our miſeries.
Stand up wretches;
Speak boldly, and have releaſe;
If ye be Chriſtians,
And by that bleſſe'd name, bound to releeve us,
Convey us from this Iſland.
Speake; what are ye?
As you are, Gentle born; to tell ye more,
Were but to number up our own calamities,
And turn your eyes wild with perpetuall weepings;
Theſe many yeers, in this moſt wretched Iſland
We two have liv'd: the ſcorne and game of fortune;
Bleſſe your ſelves from it Noble Gentlemen;
The greateſt plagues, that humane nature ſuffers,
Are ſeated here, wildneſſe, and wants innumerabIe.
How came ye hither?

In a ſhip, as you do, and as you might have
been.
Had not heaven preſerv'd ye for ſome more noble uſe;
Wrack't deſperately; our men, and all conſum'd,
But we two; that ſtill live, and ſpin out
The thin and ragged threds of our misfortunes.
Is there no meat above?
Nor meat nor quiet;
No ſummer here, to promiſe any thing;
Nor Autume, to make full the reapers hands;
The earth obdurate to the teares of heaven,
Let's nothing ſhoot but poyſoned weeds.
No Rivers, nor no pleaſant Groves, no beaſts;
All that were made for mans uſe, flye this deſart;
No aëry fowle dares makes his flight over it,
It is ſo ominous.
Serpents, and ugly things, the ſhames of nature,
Roots of malignant taſtes, foule ſtanding waters;
Sometimes we finde a fulſome Sea-root,
And that's a delicate: a Rat ſometimes,
And that we hunt like Princes in their pleaſure;
And when we take a Toad, we make a Banquet.
For heavens ſake let's aboord.
D'ee know no farther?

Yes, we have ſometimes ſeen the ſhaddow of a
place inhabited;
And heard the noyſe of hunters;
And have attempted to finde it, ſo far as a River,
Deep, ſlow, and dangerous, fenced with high Rocks,
We have gone; but not able to atchieve that hazard,
Returne to our old miſeries.
If this ſad ſtory, may diſerve your pitties,

Ye ſhall aboord with us, we will relieve your
miſeries:
Nor will we be unthankfull for this benefit;
No Gentlemen, wee'le pay for our deliverance;
Look ye that plough the Seas for wealth and pleaſures,
That out-runne day and night with your ambitions,
Looke on thoſe heaps, they ſeeme hard ragged quarries;
Remove 'em, and view 'em fully.
O heaven, they are Gold and Jewels.
Be not too haſty, here lies another heape.
And here another
All perfect gold.

Stand farther off, you muſt not be your
own carvers;
We have ſhares, and deep ones;
Yes Sir, wee'le maintain't: ho fellow Saylors.
Stand all to your freedomes;
I'le have all this.
And I this.
You ſhall be hang'd firſt.
My loſſes ſhall be made good.
So ſhall mine, or with my ſword I'le do't;
All that will ſhare with us, aſſiſt us.
Captain let's ſet in.
This money will undoe us, undoe us all:

This Gold was the overthrow of my happi-
nes;
I had command too, when I landed here,
And lead young, high, and noble ſpirits under me,

This curſed Gold entiſing 'em, they ſet upon their Cap-
tain,
On me that ow'nd this wealth, & this poor Gentleman,
Gave us no few wounds, forc'd us from our own;
And then their civill ſwords, who ſhould be owners,
And who Lords over all, turn'd againſt their own lives,
Firſt in their rage conſum'd the Ship,
That poor part of the Ship that ſcap't the firſt wracke,
Next their lives by heaps; O be you wiſe and carefull:
Wee'le ha more: Sirah, come ſhow it.

Or ten times worſe afflictions then thou ſpeak'ſt
of.
Nay, and ye will be Doggs. beats 'em out.
Let me come Captaine:
This Golden age muſt have an Iron ending.
Have at the bunch. he beats 'em off. Exit.
O Albert; O Gentlemen; O friends. Exit.
Come noble Nephew, if we ſtay here, we dye;
Here rides their Ship, yet all are gone toth' ſpoyle,
Let's make a quick uſe.
Away deer Uncle.
This Gold was our overthrow. Exit

It may now be our happineſſe. Enter Tibalt and
the reſt.
You ſhall have gold: yes, I'le crambe it int'ee;
You ſhall be your own carvers; yes, I'le carve ye.
I am ſore, I pray heare reaſon:
I'le heare none.
Covetous baſe mindes have no reaſon;
I am hurt my ſelf; but whil'ſt I have a Legge left,
I will ſo haunt your guilded ſoules; how dee Captain?
Ye bleed apace, curſe on the cauſers ont;
Ye doe not faint?
No, no; I am not ſo happy.
D'ee howle, nay, ye deſerve it:

Baſe greedy rogues; come, ſhall we make an end of
'em?

They are our country-men, for heavens ſake ſpare
em,

Alas, they are hurt enough: & they relent now. Aminta
above.
O Captain, Captain.
Whoſe voyce is that?
The Ladies.

Look Captain, look; ye are undone: poore
Captain,
We are all undone: all, all: we are all miſerable,
Mad wilfull men; ye are undone, your ſhip, your Ship.
What of her?
Shee's under Sayle and floating;
See where ſhe flies: ſee to your ſhames, you wretches:

Thoſe poor ſtarv'd things, that ſhewed you Gold. La-m.
and Franvile
goes up
to ſee the
Ship.
They have cut the Cables,
And got her out; the tyde too has befrinded em.
Where are the Saylors that kept her?
Here, here in the mutiny, to take up mony,
And left no creature, left the Boat a ſhoare too;
This Gold, this damn'd enticing Gold.
How the wind drives her,
As if it vied to force her from our furies?
Come back good old men:
Good honeſt men, come back.
The winds againſt ye, ſpeak lowder;
Ye ſhall have all your Gold againe: they ſee us.
Hold up your hands, and kneele,

And houle ye blockheads; they'le have compaſſion on
ye;
Yes, yes, 'tis very likely: ye have deſerv'd it,
D'ee look like Doggs now?
Are your mighty courages abated?
I bleed apace Tibalt:

Retire Sir; and make the beſt uſe of our
miſeries.

They but begin now. Enter
Aminta;
Are ye alive ſtill?
Yes ſweet.
Help him off Lady;
And wrap him warme, in your Armes,

Here's ſomething that's comfortable; off with him hand-
ſomely,

Il'e come to ye ſtraight: but vex theſe raſcals a little. Exit
Albert
Aminta.
Oh! I am hungry, & hurt, and I am weary.
Here's a Peſtle of a Portigue, Sir;
'Tis excellent meat, with ſoure ſauce;
And here's two Chaines, ſuppoſe 'em Sauſages;
Then there wants Muſtar'd.
But the fearefull Surgeon will ſupply ye preſently:
O for that Surgeon, I ſhall dye elſe.
Faith, there he lies in the ſame pickle too.
My ſalves, and all my Inſtruments are loſt;
And I am hurt, and ſtarv'd;
Good Sir, ſeeke for ſome Hearbs.
Here's Hearbe graceleſſe; will that ſerve?
Gentlemen, will ye goe to Supper!
Where's the meat?
Where's the meat? what a Veale voyce is there?
Would we had it Sir, or any thing elſe;
I would now cut your throat you Dogge,
But that I wo not doe you ſuch a curteſie;
To take you from the benefit of ſtarving.

O! what a comfort will your worſhip have, ſome three
dayes hence?
Yea things beneath pitty ſhall be your harbinger;
You muſt not look for down-beds here,
Nor Hangings; though I could wiſh ye ſtrong on's;
Yet here be many lightſome coole Star-chambers,
Open to every ſweet ayre, I'le aſſure ye,
Ready provided for ye, and ſo I'le leave ye;
Your firſt courſe is ſerv'd, expect the ſecond. Exit.
A vengeance on theſe Jewels.
O! this curſed Gold. Exeunt.
